Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 03:59PM theBCavenger wrote: I am three weeks out of surgery with expander's placed. I was told to sleep with my upper body elevated until my next appointment, which is Jan 5th. I have the hardest time sleeping. It has been one of the hardest parts of recovery. Also, how long did everyone wear that super tight surgical bra? I am still in mine and was wanting to wear something else tonight, as it is New Years... Any thoughts?
Posts.Title: Sleeping after Surgery mary625 Outfield

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 12:25AM theBCavenger wrote: In reading your post... have you not yet had surgery? After a needle core biopsy, I was diagnosed with stage 1 grade 1 IDC. Like you, I was not happy, but also knew it could be worse! After the MRI - I was moved to stage 3 as the tumor appeared to be on my chest wall and 4 nodes looked invaded. Also, two other tumors were discovered. I opted for a double mast with expanders placed. I made sure both the surgeon and PS understood that if clean margins were NOT obtained, no expanders (as radiation would be needed). I woke from surgery 2 weeks ago with expanders and lots of pain! I do not regret my choice for the double... here is why: They removed 32 nodes, as they were sure the cancer was there... however, the pathology showed no lymph invasion. The other two tumors were indeed cancer, but nothing was on the chest wall! I went back to stage 1. My other breast which looked perfectly clear had pre-cancer cells.  Depiste all the good news, I am told that chemo is still needed as my tumor was over 1cm. I am waiting for the results of the Oncotype DX to help me determine if chemo is really right for me.  I am sure there are a lot of stories like mine out there, and getting news with the word CANCER in it totally sucks! But remember, until the final pathology comes in, it is very hard to plan! I will pray for you to recover quickly and have amazing labs...
Posts.Title: Any diagnosed with IDC Grade 1, Stage IIa, Chase2 Chase2

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2012 04:46PM theBCavenger wrote: What an odd situation for you and your sister to be in. This is not the same, but I have an uncle who is like a father to me. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer the same week I was diagnosed. Men can be HUGE babies... and his treatment was easy and he is done, whereas, I have several procedures to go... lol. However, the greatest thing happened. He and I went through our process together and and I am so thankful for that. Not that I would wish cancer on anyone, but together we rocked!   So sorry for both of you of you to join our group :( We are here if you need us! This site has become a daily part of my life!

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 07:54AM theBCavenger wrote: Hmmm... I was given a list of things not to take 2 weeks prior to surgery, and vitamin C was on the list! The colace was a huge help for me too! One thing I wish I would have prepared for is sleeping! I had no idea how hard that part was going to be when I got home from the hospital. I am not sure if I am alone in this, but I was told I had to keep the top part of my body elevated. After two bad nights, my husband got me a wedge, but even with that, I get these horrid back pains. I really feel if the sleep was better, my recovery woud be faster. I wish you all the luck and  a speady recovery!
Posts.Title: Preparing for surgery bludaizy bludaizy

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 10:38PM theBCavenger wrote: I had very dense breast too. It is very hard for mammograms to really see anything! If I was you, I would fight for yearly MRI's, which will give them a better overall look. I was told that even though no one in my family has ever had breast cancer, I was in a higher risk group because of my breast density.  I Initially had one lump that I had discovered. After the biopsy came back positive, they sent me to MRI. Two other cancer sites where found, which did turn out to be positive, that were undetectable with mammography. I sure hope your results are all clear! Will send a prayer your way:)

Posts.Title: CHEMO??? theBCavenger theBCavenger

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2012 05:20PM theBCavenger wrote: After being called to make an appointment for mammo results, and having to wait 3 days to find out that I needed a biopsy... I made a special request of my radiologist. I begged him to call me with the results, as I did not want to have to play the waiting game.  He called me as soon as he received the results, and then continued to call to check in on me. He turned out to be the biggest help in deciding my treatment. Interesting bit: my primary care physician was really pissed about this arrangement! It turns out, he like to have patients wait for results. He and I got into it, and once my treatment plan is formalized, I will be switching to a different PCP!

He offered the test because I started freaking out over the need of an extra operation. He said if I come back low, then hormone treatment is fine. He did say that anything else, and he would like me to get the chemo... it is really my family that wants the chemo. I get it... and feel blessed they want me around. I just got done reading the Steve Jobs book, and certainly DON'T want to ignor treatment if needed... just want to make sure it is needed is all! You guys are so great! I love that we can all interact together, so helpful!
Posts.Title: CHEMO??? theBCavenger theBCavenger

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2012 02:37PM theBCavenger wrote: Butterfly - I had a BMX w/ TE's installed last December. My TE's were filled with 350cc's, which is a lot for my size, so I woke up with cleavage. It was still shocking for me. I lost both nipples and I don't think I knew about that loss before surgery. Anyway - I was totally thinking that I could do the no boob route, then I lost the TE on the bad side, and realized that I really do want boobs if I can have them. I am on this site almost everyday. There are so many different stories, strengths, weaknesses... all so very helpful. I am so sorry you had to join us, but we are all here to help you if we can. As for your pain... I was not one of the lucky one's like several that have posted here. I had horrible pain, but I do feel so much of that was brought on by the recon and my refusal to take the pain meds... That being said, I made it through the roughest part, and I know you will too.
Posts.Title: Starting to hit me... Butterflylady2012 Fierro6

But after hearing what you wrote, maybe it is not so bad that she did. I have had several showers since my first one. It is getting easier. I never really thought my boobs defined me, and to be frank, they were such a hassle that I don't mind them gone. Still on the fence about the expanders... I am sure when everything is finished, I will feel better about my choice. I hope everyone had an awesome holiday! WE ALL HAVE SO MUCH TO BE THANKFUL FOR!
Posts.Title: First Shower After Mastectomy theBCavenger rachelcarter35

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 09:57PM theBCavenger wrote: I had a BMX with TE's on Dec. 8th, 2011. They also removed 32 nodes from my cancer side. The second day after surgery was the worst day ever, and I am glad I made it through all that pain. I think a large part of the pain was caused because they filled my TE's with 350cc, and it felt like my ribs were broken. 5 weeks later, I lost my TE on the cancer side due to necrosis. That was very traumatic for me. I had to clean my wound for a week, twice a day, before I was able to have surgery. I have been living with one TE and one flat. The TE side feels great. I almost feel like I have a real boob (aside from the hardness of the TE) but the sensation is good. The cancer side is a totally different matter. If I touch one area, I get pain in another - almost as if all my nerves got mixed up or something. I too have total numbness on the backside of my arm where the nodes were taken. My DH does not understand, and grabs me there sometimes, which is most uncomfortable. I was told the numbness would most likely never go away. Got fitted for a sleeve and it should be here this week. I am looking forward to that because I think it might help my arm feel better. Sometimes, when I move in certain directions, I get what feels like an insane Charlie Horse on the outside part of my upper arm... really hurts. Still have a ton of swelling on my torso where my arm falls, and worry that it will never go away! I am having my TE replaced this next week on the 17th. I thought I would be okay without having a boob, but turns out I do want it back! My big concerns are necrosis again and the drain! I think part of the swelling is from when they pulled my last drain out! Oh, did that hurt! I so hope I won't have a drain this next week!  I am looking forward to moving on with my life and being able to handle simple chores around the house. I am thinking maybe in a year I will start to be able to really put all this behind me.       Just thankful the cancer is out!
Posts.Title: Four Months after a BMX, How's everyone doing? Cats134 Ddeal14
